UPDATED: APR 6, 2017 Aroma of cocoa, vanilla, bourbon, oak, roasted malt. Extremely smooth taste. Balanced cocoa and vanilla of the bourbon. Really a great imperial stout. Maybe the vanilla is a bit too strong, but that may be the only slight imbalance. Best Imperial stout I have had.  EDIT: 2015 version I would have rated closer to a 4. Not as smooth with not as much body, definitely not the perfect stout like past years. Weyerbacher Sunday Morning Stout I had after 2015 KBS was better, but weyerbacher SMS was quite good.  EDIT: 2016  Dominated by dry cocoa nibs and coffee aroma.  Some bourbon in taste but not a ton.  Balanced but maybe a bit bitter.  I remember much more malt and body in 2014.  Alcohol is well masked and this is mostly balanced and still a very nice imperial stout, but not mind blowing.  With 2015 and 2016 a bit more "normal" I am dropping my rating from 4.3 to 4.1.  I think CBS and Big Luscious are a step above KBS now. EDIT: 2017 coffee, bourbon, vanilla roasted malt aroma and flavor. Finish is bitter coffee and almost dry for the amount of malt. Seems slight boozy.  Bumping rating to 4.2, aroma is really fantastic. Would like more malt balancing the dry finish like it used to have though.

2013 vintage during a tasting at Julios. Sadly all we got were tastes of this great stout with no bottles available for purchase. But I finally got to taste this stuff and was not disappointed. One of the classics.
Bottle thanks to beernut! Thanks bro. Black with tan head. Aroma of bourbon and boost, some chocolate. Taste is chocolate, vanilla, bourbon. Yummy beer.

6oz pour on tap. Deep deep brown. Almost non existent head that sticks on the glass where the beer meets the glass, tan in color. Hints of toasted toffee, caramel, bourbon on the backbone. Smooth finish with a slightly dry palate. Leaves a semi warming feeling as you finish.

Single bottle from 2014 poured into wide snifter glass. Smell of bourbon .. Dark chocolate on the nose ..very dark with light creamy tan head...taste of bourbon ..bourbon and bourbon...alcohol is definitely there at 11.2 abv but not overwhelming ...mouthfeel is bang on perfect.

This one is something different .. This is a real winter warmer ..you can tell this was aged as the oak cask really cones through the taste. I can I age sipping this in the cold midwest winter on a lake.

Fantastic beer, but didnt quite live up to the hype for me. The taste fell a little short of what I expected from this beer but very happy I finally got to try it.
color black-dark brown. Strong stout but super silky ad smooth. toasty, toffy, toasty, roasty, ... everything that you can describe, but very smooth to go down. excellent work.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2014 Color café oscuro, se ve espesa y turbia. Aroma súper complejo, café expresso, vainilla, caramelo, fruta compotada. Cuerpo completo, espesa y redonda en boca, retrogusto a bourbon. Muy buena.

The 2013 bottle that I first had pours black with great head and lacing. Lots of coffee and a very well integrated bourbon. Creamy thick texture with a touch of oil. Dark chocolate. Finishes very bitter with a tiny bite of vanilla. Awesome. The 2012 bottle I had tastes just a little more subdued on the coffee side. Both bottles at Founders Churchkey event.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2016 Aroma - espresso, chocolate, caramelized sugar, alcohol, and roast.
Appearance - body is black.  The head is tan and around 1 1/2", and settles slowly.  Good lacing and alcohol cloying.
Taste - rich mix of espresso, molasses, chocolate, rich roast, and caramelized sugars.  Some of the flavors are complex and could come off as - tobacco, olives, and leather.
Palate - full bodied, the texture is slick, the carbonation is average, the finish astringent with a mix of alcohol and roast.
-----
11 May 2014

Aroma - rich espresso, alcohol, vanilla bean, and some caramelized sugar
Appearance - black body; opaque; head was about 1/6" and tan
Taste - rich in caramelized sugar, espresso, and vanilla bean, there is also a bounty of booze
Palate - body is full; texture velvety slick and thick; the carbonation is average; the finish long and strong with booze and espresso.

Ar - 8
Ap - 3
T - 9
P - 5
Ovr -17

Tried this at Savor in DC. Great beer. Poured black with a small head. Aroma has lots of coffee and bourbon. Nice gritty chocolatey notes as well. Taste is a good blend of chocolate malts and whiskey flavors. Very good texture and full flavor. Even better than the regular breakfast stout. Nice!

Bottle is 2007 vintage. Thanks Huhzubendah! Pours a pitch black with a foam head and lacing. Aroma is devastating - coffee, bourbon and chocolate. Flavor is overwhelming - intense and sublime coffee and bourbon co-mingled. Strong carbonation - alcohol is well-hidden. From notes 2/15/10.

The moment, the beer, 12:38 AM May 11, pours a thick dark heavy black pour with no appreciable head. Nose is sweet deep chocolate, espresso and whiskey. Taste is whiskey, deep malt, rich chocolate and vanilla espresso. Very smooth and velvety. Finishes is sweet with the same tasting notes with a rather long finish. Does it live up to the hype.....well find a bottle and find out. Quaff Score 9 / 10

Pours black, no head. Nose is a bit nutty, oak barrel, touch of bourbon, coffee, milk chocolate. Taste is roasty, almost milky while not being too sweet, a bit of coffee, some bourbon, chocolatey, a good amount of barrel, a little bitter and a touch dry on the finish. Extremely balanced and drinkable, hides the 11% very well. Very creamy mouthfeel. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This is really good. Bit of a thinner mouth feel than I was anticipating. Also has some heat to it. Nicely done but I think BCBS is still pretty far ahead of this one.

Draft at the House of Brews - pours dark black w/ slight tan head. Bourbon, vanilla, oak, and coffee in the aroma. The taste is more bourbon, coffee, and dark chocolate. Solid!!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Complex palate, the high alcohol content is masked exceedingly well. Has an almost tart finish. Great stout.
A black beer with a medium tan head. The aroma is roasted malt, vanilla, wood, and bourbon, less coffee than regular breakfast stout. The flavor is the same.

Wow! Pours black, slight tan creamy head. Aroma roast malt, chocolate, burbon, vanilla, molasses, anise, more burbon. Taste huge roast, coffee, chocolate, burbon, oak, vanilla, molasses. Mouthfeel perfect, smooth, alcohol bite very pleasant, balanced finish. Overall one of the best beers in the world, doesn?t get much better than this.

Fra flaske, smagt i to udgaver under pausen mellem de to fredags-session under CBC 2014, tak til Mike og Jason. Dyb sortbrun med et lavt beige skum. Cremet choko-næse med kaffe-noter - dufter faktisk af wiener melange. Bourbon-noter. Masser af booze, bourbon og bitterhed i munden, men også en fløde-agtig tekstur og en del malt-sødme. 14eren synes rå. 13eren er mere bedre - mere blød. Karakteren er et gennemsnit.

Bottle. Pours a slightly reddish espresso color with almost no head. Aroma is rich and intense chocolate covered espresso bean, bourbon, musty cork, oak, burnt caramel, sherry, port, cherry. Taste is pleasant bitter chocolate, roasted malts, and coffee fading into mellow bourbon warmth and tannins. Lingering bitter chocolate. Mouth feel lighter than I remember with some prickly carbonation, perhaps the weakest part of this beer. Very good.

12oz bottle, 2014 release. Pours a viscous black with almost no head, just a few tan bubbles. Aromas of marshmallow, strong roast, some light hops and a touch of bourbon. Taste is sweet and slightly bitter. Flavors of toasted marshmallow, some booze, although pretty light on the barrel character. Heavily roasted malts and some bitterness. Very low carbonation. Finishes sweet and slightly boozy but very refined and easily drinkable. Pretty darn good.

Huge thanks to bmoosey for this bottle! Poured at cellar temp, black with a tan head. Aroma is bourbon and vanilla, with a hint of chocolate. Taste is chocolate, vanilla, oak. Full body with a really smooth bourbon finish. This really is like sipping on a top shelf bourbon.

Pitch black with a fizzy dark brown head; No lacing. Aroma of chocolate malts, marshmallows, vanilla, coffee, and oak. Flavor consists of oak, chocolate malts, vanilla, marshmallows, roasted malts and coffee; Mildly roasty and sweet vanilla aftertaste. Heavier body with a mild creamy feeling. Very Tasty!

Bottle----> snifter. ABC Winter Haven. Ive wanted to try one of these for a long time. Aroma is big bourbon barrel notes, light roast, sweetness, and coffee. Pour is what you probably would expect. Black, viscous. Flavor was nice but predictable. Big barrel notes, sweet aspartame qualities, coffee. I like how it retained the original coffee notes. Good.
Stouts arent really my thing generally but you cannot deny that this is a phenominally well balanced beer. I havent really tasted anything like it. It really is amazing.

Very smooth on the front end with a strong bourbon finish. Very good stout. Limited release was worth the wait. If you ever have on opportunity to try, Do it!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Been sitting on this one for a few weeks waiting for a good time to open it. This is my first KBS, but Ive promised myself to be as subjective as possible. 

Dark Cola pour with a very thin, almost non existent head. Nothing but a tiny ring of tan bubbles floating around the edges. Aroma is cocoa nibs, vanilla bean ice cream, coffee (not bitter coffee like Im used to smelling in these big stouts though) and the undeniable presence of bourbon. Not in an overpowering alcohol way though, just the sweet bourbon aroma. Roasted malts and burnt chocolate start to come through a bit as the beer warms up. This beer smells pretty damn good. More so than I was expecting actually. Its not super pungent and in your face, but a mellow complexity that gets better the longer the beer sits in the glass. Flavor is a little more intense than the aroma. Bitter chocolate and coffee envelop your palate, followed by some nice roasted characteristics, vanilla, and bourbon. Warms your body like a shot of whiskey. Very drinkable despite the 11.2% abv. You know the alcohol is there though, dont get me wrong. Its just not abrasive like some barrel aged stouts Ive had in the past. This beer is delicious and begs to be sipped and enjoyed. The flavors continue to develop as the beer warms and each sips reveals something a little bit different. Overall this is an excellent beer and worthy of recognition. That being said, Im not sure its worth the trouble it is to track this thing down. Multiple phone calls and trips to multiple stores before finally grabbing the last two bottles at a shop a couple towns over. I wont bend over backwards to find this one again, but Im glad I got to experience it. Truly one of the "must try" beers in America.

Have waited a long time to try this highly sought after bourbon barrel stout. Had the 2012 and 2014 vintages side by side and the differences are noticeable. Both have that great pitch dark appearance and vanilla/bourbon nose. The 2014 is very coffee forward as would be expected whilst the 2012 had a mellow chocolate feel. Lives up to the hype? Without a doubt. This is world class.

Very excited to finally break into a bottle of KBS and Im not sharing either. Its a beautiful looking beer, pitch black, basically no head retention, thick and oily. Ok so at first this thing smelled like oxidized and burnt coffee and tasted pretty oxidized too and I cant verify how old my bottle was. I was honestly pretty turned off by it at first. Burnt, stale, bitter coffee, old wood, cereal grains and cocoa powder. As it warmed up however, I started to enjoy it more- deeper chocolate notes, vanilla cream, not a lot of heat on it anymore. The coffee warms up very nicely too as this beer opened up. Very glad I got to try this and I want to try another again, maybe fresher. Best imperial Stout? No. Second best? No. Overrated? Yes.

Tallahassee, Fl. - Proof Brewing Company - on tap. Smooth top shelf bourbon aroma, a touch of creosote. Solid, robust flavor with some bittersweet bakers chocolate, top shelf bourbon - going to go with Wild Turkey, some licorice notes. Smooth, velvety mouthfeel. Not the biggest BA fan, but this one is done up right - no cloying, soy sauce or kids vitamins.

Everything about it is excellent. Hints of Bourbon with little head. A mixture of chocolate and vanilla-coffee. Rich, dark beer - black as a moonless night. The first sip stops everything. Beautifully complex and warm. After drinking, the taste says - drink more. And you do. Overall, this beer has to be the best beer - period.

Possibly the best beer Ive ever had, pours pitch black with a small film of dark khaki head. Taste is strong bourbon to start and once it warm a lot more of the coffee and vanilla notes shine through, there are also chocolate undertones.

Pours a dark coffee black with slight tan creamy head. Aroma is of dark chocolate and coffee. Taste is very chocolate with coffee and bourbon back end. Very good stout. A bit syrupy on the palate bit that is expected with this much chocolate taste. The alcohol is hidden well.
Poured from the bottle a nice pitch black. Very heavy on the chocolate and coffee smell.

Served out of a bottle. Thin head. Aroma is subtle, but coffee, oak, vanilla, and hints of the Bourbon. Tastes of chocolate and bourbon up front, slowing turning into a distinct marshmallow flavor, and ending with coffee and oak.
If this is what they drink for breakfast in Kentucky then I definitely need to visit. Forget Irish coffees, next time Im trying mine with bourbon.

Pours a dark black. Has a strong malt, liquorish, and heavy dark alcohol aroma. Taste is very strong and unique with some coffee, vanilla, dark alcohol (from the bourbon barrels), oak, and some malts. A smooth aftertaste as if it were a fine bourbon. Nothing bitter or overwhelming about this beer!

Smells like chocolate syrup, vanilla, and a hint of toasty oak. Appears opaque dark brown with caramel foam, minimal lace. Taste is of chocolate up front followed by some bitter cocoa coffee and oak, with a touch of bourbon sweetness and minor alcohol burn. Palate is a bit syrupy. Overall, good, probably best in small doses; the flavor is a bit overwhelming.

Tap (niiice). Pitch black. Minimal head and lacing. Incredibly creamy. Nose predominantly bourbon. Tastes like drink chocolate, with an edge of bourbon to balance any sweetness. Slightly boozey. Lives up to the height.

Very happy I was able to try this one. On tap. A: chocolate, coffee, alcohol. Ap: dark brown with a small tan head. T: bitter with the Bourbon coming through at the end. P: sticky with a pronounced Bourbon taste and just lingers. O: delicious and a top 5 beer for me.

Amazing !!!! So good so very very good! The nose is remarkable oak an dark sweetness with an obvious high ABV nose tickle. The taste is so well balanced with a sweet yet bitterness at 70 IBUs loving the silky mouth feel with coffee an bourbon back end. WELL DONE Founders
Great beer when you can find it. Vanilla and coffee tastes mix so well here.

Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head that lasts forever. Aroma is chocolate, nut, and oak bourbon. Taste is heavily bourbon, a nice dose of sweet chocolate, and some coffee that comes out stronger as the beer warms up. Has a full body feel and goes down smooth. This is a delicious beer that lives up to the hype, even if the bourbon is a tad overpowering.

4/18/14 bought for $7.99 @ CBO. Was last to grab a ticket. Drank as a celebration after getting the job as manager. I liked it but fell well below BCBS 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Big vanilla, bourbon, and bacon. Smoky bourbon and vanilla on the first sip. Nice tan brown caramel head, and chocolate liquid gold. Outstanding

Immediate aroma of cocoa. Thin tan head on a dark brown deep pour. An immediate cocoa ( not chocolate) and coffee taste. Perfect taste. , not overpowering. Note: the foam turned a dark tan as I drank it. Worth the hype. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy

Draft at the Capitol-Bloomsburg. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Leaves trace lacing in the glass. Big roasted malt notes on the nose with a hint of bourbon. The bourbon notes are subtle on the tongue but they expand on the maltiness as the beer warms. A bit of lactic on the finish but its also remarkably smooth and hides it alcohol well. A damn good beer.

Pour - black. No head. 

Aroma - slight caramel. 

Mouth - lightly oily. Low carb. 

Taste - nothing up front but after swallow. Slightly hoppy on the finish then a rush if coffee and slight bourbon. 

Overall - excellent. Bourbon comes through the longer you drink. Coffee at the start. Not for sessions.
This is my all time favorite! Very hard to find. Nice bourbon smell on the nose and a smooth bourbon vanilla taste!

Love having a Friday off, so Im celebrating with KBS. Just a fantastic coffee aroma on the nose, nice and dark appearance. Smooth mouth feel, coffee, cocoa, and a little roasty malt on the palate. Toffee on the finish. Overall, a great beer.

Pours an inky black with a thick brown head. Aromas of coconut, coffee and malts. Cask aging is up front and powerful with notes of coconut and coffee in the middle with a malty after taste. Excellent beer, worth the cost and then some.
Just as good as the goose island coffee bourbon aged stout. I love the founders breakfast stout and this is almost heaven. It is worth the hunt.

Opaque coffee color. Viscous pour. Sensuous nose - vanilla, whiskey roast, sweet. Whiskey and chocolate, sweet like a Jack Daniels mudslide. Warming. Mouthy, quality oily body. Not hugely bitter. A bit tarry at the end. Sweet roast finish. Reminds me of some familiar chocolate/toffee/caramel candy from childhood. Tap, Proof.

Draft into a 5 oz tasting glass. Deep dark color with an intentionally poured small tan head. Very smooth and subtle build of bourbon flavor with a nice lingering taste left of the palate. Finally got to try it and it lives up to the fame!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle pour- black with thin tan head, aromas and flavors of cocoa, coffee, and prominent bourbon. Smooth, long finish. Delicious brew!
UPDATED: APR 28, 2014 This is 2nd only to Goose a Island Bourbon County Brand Coffee Stout. Regular BCBS feel behind because I love coffee in my stout
Tap at Farmhouse and 12 ozers at home. Everything youd want on a late winters night by the fire. Strong nose of bourbon, earth, peat, caramels. Once again, proof that god loves us.

Poured at home from a 12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark black with a thin tan head. Smell is of coffee and cocoa with a little sweet vanilla. Taste is cocoa, with coffee and vanilla. Theres that little burn in the back of your throat from the bourbon at the end. Medium body. Overall, an awesome beer with a lot going on...Definitely recommend!

Black with a thin tan head. Sweet vanilla aroma. Smooth sweet coco bourbon and vanilla. Medium bodied and silky

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Thought for sure Id already had this. Tap at Proof. Black pour. Huge roasty chocolate aroma. Creamy vanilla, chocolate, light bourbon, wood. Bittersweet. Awesome balance. 8.6

Bottle, for my 1000th rating. Pours motor-oil brown/black with a high, mixed-grain, tan head. Nose is good bourbon, coffee, vanilla, and a touch of soy -- really amazing; the bourbon comes right through. On the tongue, heavy and dark; not as sweet as I expected, with the best encapsulation of bourbon Ive ever tasted in a beer along with coffee, vanilla, and a touch of savory. The palate is oily smooth with a long, satisfying, heated richness. Worth the hype.

Pours black with a tan head into a snifter. 

Aroma is of bourbon, chocolate, and coffee. Unlike most BA stouts, the bourbon isnt in the forefront, but mixed in and balanced nicely with the other ingredients.

Taste follows the aroma, a nice balance of all three of the main characteristics. Bourbon and vanilla, chocolate, with some coffee. Strong bourbon aftertaste along with the coffee. Absolutely fantastic. A little boozy at the end, but age should take this out.

Thick and oily on the palate, exactly how I like my stouts. 

An exceptional twist on the BA stout style, and unlike most of the others, this one doesnt let the bourbon overshadow the chocolate and coffee. Its perfectly balanced, perfectly drinkable. Age could mellow out the boozy bite at the end, but this is a damn near perfect beer.

Deserves all the hype! This beer is amazing. One of, if not, the best tasting beer I've ever tried. Almost complete perfection, the only thing I could even consider dinging it for is it is a little thinner than I'd like (and by just a hair), but that's not to say that this beer could be much better. World class for sure!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours pitch black with a tan head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is strong vanilla bourbon and a little booze. Mouthfeel is viscous but very smooth for such a high alcohol beer. The immediate taste is of chocolate and coffee with just the tiniest bit of alcohol on the back end. There is a very long and pleasant vanilla and bourbon aftertaste with a vanilla nose. Very, very good, and glad we were able to get it in NJ this year.
I thoroughly enjoy this beer. This rating is based on the fresh '14 batch. Slightly sharp on the booziness. Could use a year or so in the cellar.
Bottle shared with lamont ..megan..Chelsea. .. pitch black pour with brown head. .chocolate arome..smooth taste..syrupy heaven...Love it!

A perfect Imperial Stout. From beginning to end, it all flows together without a single "bump". Beautiful color, great head & aroma, and on the palate, it is without measure. Definitely worth the price & if you can find it on tap...get it!

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep brown to black color with a thin rim of brown head. Aroma is full of chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, roasted malts. Flavor is quite sweet, chocolatey goodness, with a hot bourbony boozy burn. Molasses. Medium body with a lingering boozy burn and a cocoa sweetness. Always a favorite of mine!

Very pleasant aroma w/hints of Coffee. A sweet coffee taste w/the Bourbon overtones. Very good on the palate leaving a mix of the coffee and bourbon but not boozy at all. Overall its as good as advertised if not better. 2014 version.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2014 2014 vintage bottle at The Globe Pub, Chicago. Appearance is black with little to no head. Aroma is coffee caramel. Taste is bourbon first with a lovely sweetness. Not a strong coffee flavour, but what does come out is the roasty bitterness. As it warms strong caramel butterscotch flavours come out. Lovely. A truly great barrel aged stout. Barrel doesnt overwhelm the base beer but adds to it.

On tap surprisingly at Alley Bar. Incredibly smooth and rich. Really does live up to the reputation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours almost black with no head. Nose is chocolate, dark fruit and alcohol. Taste is lots of alcohol.  Tastes smoother as it warms up.

12oz bottle.
Pours absolutely pitch black, with a brown head.
Massive,complex aroma, roasted malt, coffee, oak, vanilla, licorice, tar.
Sweet, full bodied, high bitterness, creamy CO2.
Rich, velvety, hugely complex taste, layer upon layer of dark malt, chocolate, oak, vanilla, coffee, chocolate, licorice.
The finish is everlasting, with loads of subtle nuances coming through. A really great beer, that actually lives up to the massive hype. (2014-04-10)
Best example of a stout I have ever had. Nice balanced beer with great finish. Best when allowed time to warm up a liitle.

On tap at upick6 release party in Erie, PA on 04-09. First time ever getting to try this. Pour was jet black with a khaki colored head. Minimal lacing. Beautiful aroma of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, toast. Had a nice sweet chocolate start to it and then the coffee came in with a nice bourbon finish. Palate was oily feel. It was a very filling beer. I only had one, but I had other beers before the relase so maybe I was just full. Id love to get ahold of some more of these. I now see what the hype is about!

Can't say a single bad thing about this beer.... Amazing and spectacular - the sweet and bitter notes of vanilla, chocolate, and coffee blend perfectly well with the sweet, thick stout base.... Having had Founder's Breakfast Stout, I can say that there is a considerable difference... The hype is very well earned!

Aroma: Dark Fruit, bourbon, some coffee
Appearance: Motor oil best describes this beer, small brown head, high lacing, medium to high carbonation
Taste: smooth, dark fruits, bourbon, alcohol, woody, lots of chocolate, dark malts, slight alcohol.
Palate: Oily and chewy
Overall: 2 years waiting to finally try this, on tap I might add. Lives up to the hype, as the bourbon compliments all the dark fruits and other flavors in this beer. Would love to age a bottle. 200th rating

Bottle. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, oak, and booze. Appearance is black with a light brown head. Good lacing. Taste is vanilla, chocolate, coffee, oak, bourbon, and toast. Long aftertaste of bourbon, coffee, and roasted barley. Full body with low carbonation. Overall complex, delicious, robust, and work seeking out every year.

Tasted it on draft at Venos in Little Rock, AR last week. Incredible is all I can say! Smelled of coffee and chocolate with a very nice finish of molasses and bourbon. Amazing beer from top to bottom!

2014. Pours a jet black with aroma of bourbon and vanilla. Taste is of coffee, vanilla, and undertones of vanilla. Hides the alcohol very well!! Amazing beer! Worth all the hype!

----Hophaze out

On draft at Nick's in Bloomington believe it or not. Pours motor oil black with a nice tan head. The aroma is strong coffee and roasted malt with hints of bourbon. The original Founders Breakfast Stout is clearly present in this Imperial Stout. The bourbon flavor is present throughout, but not as strong and overpowering like a Bourbon County Brand Stout. Overall a great imperial stout. Mine got better as it warmed to room temp. The roasted malt, coffee, and oatmeal flavors blend well with the bourbon in this stout. Smooth as silk. The 11.2% ABV is hidden well and basically not present. Overall an amazing beer. Worthy of the hype. Can't wait to age by bottles and open this gem in a few months. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2014 release poured into a shifter. 

Appearance is black as a tire. Low extremely low carbonation leaves little to no head. Brew is medium body that does cling to the glass.

Aroma is mainly bourbon with oak and vanilla tones to an extremely pleasant degree without over doing it. 

Taste is bourbon, slightly alcoholic, and vanilla that leads into an oaky chocolate. Perfect. Breathing in through your nose after a sip shows the dramatic perfect present in this beer. 

Palate is smooth. With low carbonation and these taste components Id believe that this was bottled on nitro with how smooth is. After its gone, the IBUs bring that little bit of bitterness that dries out your mouth and makes you want more. 

Overall, pretty darn close to perfection if you ask me. Taken me 2 years to get my hands on one and now I see why this is highly sought after. Ill be spending another 2 years looking for it. 

Time to shut up and enjoy the rest!

On tap. Pours black with a medium and lingering dark beige head. The aroma is potent, with lots of vanilla and bourbon. It has a healthy amount of roasted malts and coffee, to go along with some chocolate. The taste retains lots of bourbon and vanilla. I find some potent caramel and licorice notes, along with some chocolate that is found throughout. The aftertaste is long with that combination of bourbon and vanilla. The body is medium to full, with a slick and very oily texture. Carbonation seems to be lacking for the most part. I found this to be very easy to drink. All of the impressions work very well together. It is very tasty and the alcohol content is very subtle. Im quite surprised that this is as strong as it actually is. Altogether, this is an amazing stout. Its tough to get much better than this.
Good God this beer is excellent. Perfect balance of wood and licorice. A beer mans beer. You will not find a better stout.

On tap in snifter glass. Pitch black with little head, good body - sticks to the glass. Aroma of chocolate and bourbon. Tastes of bourbon, oak, coffee and loads of chocolate.....chocolate flavor lingers after swallowing. Alcohol is well hidden but still noticable. Warming makes the bourbon and chocolate more pronounced. Fantastic beer. Not sure if its better than BCBS though.

Porzo syrup black beer with a large deep chocolate brown. Aroma is molasses chocolate some coffee lots of bourbon. Tases chocolate coffee whiskey molasses birch sugar with a long whiskey and Oak finish. Mouth feel is thick and oily.
UPDATED: MAY 21, 2014 Bourbany, very slight caramel.  Defenitely can taste the alcohol.  Did not like.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2014 Pours a dense viscous ruby highlighted black oil. Medium dense tan head that dissipated rather quickly. Coffee bourbon and hot alcohol rape your rose. Coffee dark caramel bourbon and chocolate fill your mouth with a silky wave gift from Founders. This is one beer that doesnt disappoint.

So happy to get one of these this year in Virginia! Almost the perfect beer. Dark color with a chocolate and coffee scent. Tasty coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and finishes with bourbon. Absolutely the best stout out there.

Poured into sniffer. 2014. Color is dark and aroma is strong of bourbon. Palate on this beer is top notch. Alcohol comes through strong but I like that in a bourbon aged beer. Taste is rich but still complex.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2014 Rich coffee up front. Dark chocolate liquor as it warms. Sweet vanilla and caramel bourbon throughout. Undertones of molasses, cream, toffee, dark fruit and espresso. A powerhouse of a beer. I?d like a slightly fuller body but really that?s just splitting hairs.
UPDATED: MAR 14, 2016 Simply one of the best beers I?ve ever had. Such a smooth blend of Bourbon, chocolate, and coffee.

2014 release bottle into snifter. Just an incredible beer. Super balanced stout. The bourbon is top notch. The base beer is typical Founders greatness. Brilliant!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2014 bottle. Ill tell ya, I visited 5 different places around Columbus to score a total of 4 bottles of this stuff for 2014 at about $6 a pop plus tax. I got a single 2013 bottle last year thats still on my shelf. Straight up, this beer is overrated. Im not saying it isnt great, but its just not as good as the hype suggests. Bourbon County Stout crushes this stuff. Dark Lord too, though very different. 

Served in snifter. Effectively opaque black; foamy-frothy dark brown head. Improves vastly as it approaches room temperature. Aroma extremely heavy chocolate, sweet, malt, vanilla, coffee, alcohol warmth; subtle oak. Big big flavor is heavier on the coffee than I prefer, yet not heavy enough to be an all-out coffee stout; lot of booze here too. The bourbon is almost imperceptible at fridge temperature but theres still a lot of chocolate and vanilla. At room temperature, the bourbon is much more in-your-face. Smooth, bubbly, frothy, heavy mouthfeel is big but somehow not massive; sticky. Really very good, but Id be hard-pressed to make tons of special trips to get this for myself in future years. Over-hyped and the trade potential is the only thing that justifies the hunt for this.

Walking into a store 5 minutes after its official release and the one case is already sold out.  A young kid and his girlfriend appearing heartbroken that they were on the special email list and still too late 15 minutes after release. A Giant Eagle with a single case selling 2 bottles to a person when youre lucky to get 1 anywhere else. 

Its a really, really good beer, but the anecdotes around finding this drink overshadow the beer itself.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2014 First impressions are the sweetness, alcohol, coffee and bourbon. Molasses. Vanilla. Just slight touches of tar, tobacco.

Interesting soft vanilla mouth feel. Body is just a bit light for a bourbon-barrel imperial stout.

Not as "Roasted" as some Imperial Stouts. 

An excellent beer, though Id rate it a bit below the RB average. A bit too dominated by the alcohol and bourbon. Would like to taste a bit more of the dried fruits.

5/17/2014 notes: re-rating a beer can be a humbling experience. Drinking it tonight I really notice the chocolate on the finish.  Really missed it before...

UPDATED: APR 24, 2014 Bottle->snifter. Black with medium tan head. A: gorgeous blend of chocolate, bourbon, coffee, vanilla, oak. T: same, with vanilla front dropping to a dark roasty chocolate and coffee finish. Nice bitter end, great mouthfeel. One of the few beers that truly meets its hype. Outstanding.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2014 On tap, 4/4/2014. Molasses and maple aromas. Weak chocolate brown head. Slams you with a dark chocolate milkshake flavor, syrup sweetness, a residual caramel layer left after the gulp. High ABV is well disguised, like a boozy milkshake. This beer is evil...because one could enjoy it all say everyday, but its only possible to for a few moments in April. Thats the worst April Fools joke.

12 oz bottle from CT Beverage in New Britain, CT.  This beer is very elusive a one to a customer limit.  Pour is jet black with motor oil thickness, a thin beige head and big alcohol legs.  Smell is equal parts dark chocolate and espresso with notes of wood, charcoal and booze.  Taste is similar to the nose with some nice elements of vanilla and oak with a charred bitterness that works well with the sweet malt.  Bourbon really shines through on the back end and actually cleanses the palate in between sips.  The barrel aging really helped this beer and us a big improvement over the Breakfast stout which I thought was a coffee saturated overrated mess.  The bourbon, oak and vanilla really make this complex and enjoyable and the coffee, although present, doesn't dominate the beer.  Love to have an aged version of this but I'm not sure if I'll get my hands on another one.

Draft. Pours black with a red hue. No head or carbonation. Rich coffee chocolate aromas. The bourbon vanilla flsvor dominates this superb beer. Boozy but appropriate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fantastic Bourbon stout. the aroma is of coffee chocolate and bourbon, and the taste gives you more of the same, wha tthis does better than te BCBS is that the bourbon is more balanced in the flavor and complements the base beer instead of overpowering it. overall a delicious and dangerously drinkable beer

This beer is in the top 5 for its class. Aroma is choc, bourbon, strong vanilla. Appearance is dark with a persistent head with lacing that stays from start to finish. Taste is a well balanced bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, chocolate. Palate is full but not sticky. Gotta try it if u can find it.

Definitely a high quality stout. The bourbon barrel really comes through, more so than any other barrel aged stout Ive had. Great beer but doesnt blow me away like a BCBS. More than worth the $5 price tag.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2015 Bottle 2014. Pours very dark cola, basically black, no head. Aroma is bourbon, oak, cocoa, coffee, roasted malt, and more bourbon. The taste is super complex - follows the aroma in smooth stages - bourbon barrel, sweet and bitter chocolate, some vanilla. Very well balanced flavors with boozy heat, of course, due to the freshness factor. Iâm getting some slight dark cherry notes on the finish. The mouthfeel is actually lighter bodied than I expected making it so smooth and drinkable. Warm, low carb. Excellent. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From the 2014 batch. The pour is deep black with a short-lived dark brown head. The aroma has a vanilla and coffee feel to it but it is not extreme. I am also picking up some booze on the nose. The body is a little under medium but generally smooth. The taste tends to lean toward the dark malts and booze more than the promised coffee. A ripe fruit character can be picked up too.

2014 bottle poured into Founders Brewing Co. snifter a motor oil syrup with a dark tan head that laced nicely down the side of the glass.
Aroma is sweet coffee dark chocolate with subtle booze.
Flavor knocks my socks off (every year). Toffee coffee chocolate even some slight tobacco. Booze is less in taste than it was in aroma which is impressive.
Feels full to the mouth & so balanced. Such an impressive seasonal which each year is well worth the wait to purchase. Yummo!

2014 poured from bottle into Founders snifter. Aroma is chocolate and alcohol. Appearance is dark brown almost black allowing virtually no light to pass through it. Had about a 1/2 finger tan head that dissipates to a foamy head around the perimeter of the glass. Taste is coffee chocolate and a bit of vanilla. There is also a slight sourness that adds to the enjoyment of this beer. Palate is very good, smooth and nicely carbonated. Overall ... excellent.

Here's an example of a beer that lives up to the hype. Pours a opaque black with a creamy beige head. Aroma is full of coffee, bitter chocolate, bourbon, dark sweet malt, light hop. Almost tastes like a rich creamy chocolate bourbon cake, so thick and smooth. Cookie dough, cake, sweet chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, light oak all flood your taste buds. Let me emphasize, this is exceptionally easy to drink.. Bourbon is not overpowering, but very clear and lovely. Finish is very complex, it goes back and forth between bitter and sweet perfectly. Killer stuff

Right up there with bcbs, though this has a bit more tobacco and toffee/vanilla. Very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured a deep, deep black with a faint head. Nice nose. Very, smooth in the mouth with alcohol well hidden, probably dangerously so. Would love to be able to age one of these.

medium body, creamy, long finish,caramel, roasty, chocolate, 
Finally able to get my hands on a bottle of this much hyped beer. It did NOT disappoint. Very impressed, lots of dark chocolate taste, and a beautiful finish. Leaves me wanting more.

Deeply chocolate. A little Bourbon and very sweet, tons of coffee that lingers. I drove 200 miles to get this beer and it was definitely worth it. This is a fantastic stout, it hides the crazy alcohol extremely well! This is one of the greats and Im happy to get to taste it!

Here it is. This is a 12 oz. bottle poured into a snifter. It pours a velvety dark brown/black color. The head is tan/brown, fluffy, and leaves a lot of lacing. The aroma is equal parts coffee and dark chocolate, with hints of booze and vanilla. This isnt a coffee-forward as FBS, but its no slouch in that arena either. The taste is coffee upfront followed by chocolate and roasted malts. Im getting very little in the way of vanilla, caramel, oak, or other BBA flavors. Incredibly smooth, silky, full mouthfeel. I dont like this quite as much as FIS, but it is fantastic.

On tap strong bourban taste with coffee and vanilla.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had three 8 oz draft pours during KBS Week last week, but I havent tried the bottles yet.

Deep black, impeccable aroma, flavors of bourbon, dark chocolate, roasted malt. Lovely beer - I wish there were a way to have this year round.

The only slight negative I had was that odd tinny sweetness on the palate. Founders beers are usually balanced perfectly, so this stuck out to me.

Speaking of balance, though, the bourbon barrel flavor comes through strong, but not obnoxious. Thats exactly what Im looking for in a barrel aged beer.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2015 Updated 7/15 with a pour from The Petrol Station Houston.  A bit less complexity on the aroma this time.  Still a fantastic beer.

2013 Bottle obtained locally in a trade, and re-rated with a 2014 bottle from Columbus BeveragePoured into a snifter. Pours black with little head. What head is present is khaki and disappears quickly. Aroma is bourbon and oak up front, followed by vanilla and chocolate malts. Very complex and well developed. Taste is bourbon forward, followed by semi sweet caramel malts and cocoa nibs. Hints of vanilla. Light bitterness present.  Finishes dry. Palate is surprisingly thin, lightly carbonated with lingering bitterness. Overall a complex flavor profile, very good beer. Lots going on.  Very enjoyable!
Best stout ever. Worth the 2 hour drive to Founders. Its all good and stuff. Serious.
Coffee and booze on the nose, chocolate an booze on the tongue. Smile on my face!
Amazing. Had several pints on tap. Like the breakfast stout but with a distinct bourbon flavor.

Wow, shared by a fellow beer lover at work who went to Grand Rapids for the release. Very dark black color. Aroma of dried fruit, coffee, bourbon and chocolate. The taste is essentially identical to the aroma. Body is lighter than most other stouts. The taste evolves as it warms - try it cold, and then enjoy how it changes as it warms. One of the best stouts Ive ever tried.
Props to Founders for another great batch! The week long release was well done.
As close to perfect as you can get. Bourbon taste is excellent without over powering at all.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2015 Bottle from trade. Liquorice, chocolate, coffee, soy, alcohol, nice.

Rerate after I had another bottle that was 1 year old. Much less impressed now, more bitter, less chocolate notes.
2013 Bottle. While a year old when I tried it, the carbonation lightened the overall impact of the beer. Improved greatly as it warmed. One of my favorites.

Pours a thick black with a little ring of dark brown head before quickly disappearing. Great aromas of vanilla, bourbon, and burnt sugar. Vanilla and bourbon flavors at first and then a nice dark chocolate finish. Thanks kathouse for this beauty. A wonderful stout.

Poured from bottle to glass. Jet black hue with tan head that dissipated to thin ring. Aroma is vanilla, cinnamon, wood, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, dates, cola. Mouthfeel is great with a full body and good carbonation. Taste is sweet throughout with a nice astringentness in the finish. Overall this a fantastically well balanced bourbon stout.
2013 bottle. Aroma is coffee, booze and oak. Slight head with very little lacing. Tastes like chocolate with a coffee and whiskey aftertaste. Great after a year of aging

Amazing bourbon taste. Extremely tasty beer. Overall very good and happy to have tried 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 13, 2014 2013. From notes, consumed on 4/7/13. Bottle (2013) poured into a snifter served around room temperature. Pours jet black with a finger of tan head. Aromas of bourbon, coffee, chocolate, coconut, slight cinnamon and dark fruit. Tasting notes of bourbon, chocolate, coffee, coconut. Full body with a semi-dry finish. 10/4/10/5/19

2014. Draft at GBD poured into a snifter, 12 ounces I think. Pours black with tan head. Aromas of roast, caramel, vanilla, dark chocolate. Tasting notes of roasty coffee, bourbon, oak, dark chocolate. Full body with an oily mouthfeel. 8/4/9/4/18. Score averaged with original rating, rounded down for any x.5 values.

[Bottle / fresh] Dark as hell, borderline oil viscosity with a slowly forming, deep-tan head that rises, perches, & leaves minor webbing on the glass during its decent. Bourbon aroma, but one of the tamest & smoothest Ive encountered. Warming notes of wood, toasted nuttiness, coffee beans, borderline bitter roast, & a decadent undercurrent of malty sweetness, a la coffee cream & sugar... Brown sugar, to be exact. Warmth brings out an enormous dark fudge character; bittersweet, savory, dense. Taste is incredibly smooth, just like the aroma would indicate. Notes of syrupy bourbon, hinting at maple, wet oak, promising vanilla, roasted maltiness, & rich, dark fudge cake. Finish of bittersweet chocolate morsels, tame bourbon, wood, nuts, & mild coffee. Very nice mouth feel... It isnt the best stout Ive ever had, not by any means - but its still amazing & fairly deserving of the hype it gets.
[Bottle / 2010 / 3 years old] Surprisingly more bourbon flavor in the three year old bottle, yet its even more smooth & void of any real burn (or warmth at all) which makes it slide down like nothing. Understandably, the coffee is more tame, but the rich fudge & chocolate flavors come out even more. I like it better fresh, but non-coffee lovers might enjoy some age on this fine beer.
Great stout, but the key is aging. Year one this beer tastes way too much like bourbon (if there could be such a thing). By year 3 of bottle aging, you get a distinct chocolate milk sensation.

This is a knock your sox off beer. Just a small handful of other stouts can close to compare to it. Fortunately it is very limited production because you cant spoil yourself having it everyday. 2 or 3 times a year is plenty. If you havent tried it, do what you can to get a bottle. Comes out around 4/1 so get on your favorite sellers to notife you when it come out as it will be sold out the same day.
A wonderfully unique tastw. Definitely a great substitute for coffee in the AM. Hints of both bourbon and coffee are well balanced for crisp finish with lingering taste on palate.

One of the beers shared at Christmas. Dark like motor oil with a very small dark tan head. Aroma is amazing... coffee, vanilla with hints of chocolate and bourbon. Flavor also amazing with similar highlights... Maybe Santa will bring for of this next year!!

Not what I want in an imperial stout. Buttery caramel cloying sweetness. There is nothing I hate more that sweet beer. I know its made well, I understand the reasoning behind barrel aging this in Bourbon, but its not my thing and Im not impartial enough to see through that.

Sampled from bottle many times. Pours black with deeper brownish tones. Aromas of sweet bourbon, fresh coffee, milk chocolate, and dry roast. The palate is medium silky, with flavors of big chocolate covered almond, oak barrel, and coffee grounds. Medium body that gets thinner as you drink it. Nice beer, but has been passed by many others of the same style/treatment.

2013 bottle. Reviewed from notes. Rcvd in trade. Consumed April 18, 2013.
The appearance has a dark brown/almost black colored body, tan foamy head as it rises and falls slowly but nicely enough to leave some nice clingy slightly foamy lacing in the wake. The smell has some bourbon up front with coffee, chocolate and oak coming through to try and combine with the bourbon but still stays secondary, vanilla only comes out as it warms. The taste is slightly sweet, but burnt/roasty/smokiness of sorts goin on, vanilla comes out again but subdued, hmmm...yes a bourbon aftertaste and finish. On the palate, its pretty heavy, yet smooth and rich, not sessionable (nowhere close, not sure why I had two of these tonight, but I know Im goin to bed after this), boy oh boy that ABV is felt [the heat is there], carbonation is adequate. Overall, this is smooth, wow, what a nice mouthfeel, I can see why so many people absolutely love this, and it has so many complexities, however, almost think I need to have one more and let it age just a bit just to see how it does, other than that, this is one Id have again, and is definitely worth the hype.

Bottle courtesy of Kermis... Big thanks. Poured a deep mahogany with a thin tan head. The aroma is malt coffee creamy caramel dark chocolate and some boozy alcohol bitterness. The flavour is medium to strong bitter with a super smooth creamy liqourice malt palate and a short bitter finish. Full bodied with flat carbonation. Boy is this good. I probably could drink this with breakfast. In fact to hell with breakfast at all. Ill just drink this!
One of my favorites! Pours a midnight black and smells of oak, coffee and vanilla. Taste is so smooth with lingering tones of bourbon that leave you desiring for this beer to never end!
Pours a deep dark brown, nearly black color with tan head. Big bourbon aroma, chocolate, roast, alcohol. Much of the same in the flavor, big bourbon, chocolate, and roastiness. Very yummmmy.

2011 vintage; will have to revisit rating when I have a fresh bottle. Aroma has a moderate chocolate and bourbon character with lighter notes of coffee and vanilla. Medium light alcohol note and light oak. Pours black with some dark brown highlights. Thin dark tan head that recedes fairly quickly to the edges. Light lacing and medium legs. Flavor has a moderate sweet chocolate note with moderate coffee character - definitely more coffee than in the aroma. Medium light bourbon character with faint oak and vanilla. Medium alcohol spice in the finish. Light dark fruit esters and some oxidation are starting to show. Mouthfeel is full bodied with medium low carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. Overall even with age this beer is very enjoyable. The flavor is showing hints of oxidation and the aroma doesn?t have much coffee character, but the bourbon notes have mellowed nicely. I think I actually like the beer with a bit of age but it has to be well cellared.

35cl Bottle shared, thank you so much for this gem JulienHuxley!! Black colour, beige-brown head. Aroma of full-on rich chocolate and soft smooth bourbon, later on some more hard roasted malts and a little booze shines through. Flavour is vanilla, oak, lovely smooth bourbon (oak-ageing is perfectly done imho), hard roasted malts, quite bitter but also sweet, chocolate, chocolate brownie, nice roasted bitter finish with a little vanilla. Coffee is kept in check, thank God. Full-bodied, smooth mouthfeel. Really glorious stuff.
Bottle at Vail. Thanks to adnielsen for sharing. Pours a black color with tan head. Bourbon, vanilla, coffee, chocolate aromas. Nice oak, bourbon, chocolate, coffee, vanilla flavors. So fucking good.

Bottle at Taco Mac. Finally found one of these!! I was worried that it wouldnt be worth the hype, but those fears were dispelled with the first sip. Pours near black with a thin mocha cap. Aroma is filled with chocolate, coffee, vanilla and a nice mellow bourbon. The taste has all those elements as well - but the oakiness and vanilla are a bit more pronounced. I really like how the bourbon complements rather than dominates in this beer. Silky smooth full mouthfeel. Sweet without being sticky or syrupy. Tremendous beer.
Amazing stuff. Rich coffee, chocolate and bourbon on nose. Add those with some extra dark fruit and licorice notes and you have a winner. The mouth feel is silky and smooth.

Latest review: Vintage 2012, reviewed 02MAY12
This one pours black as ever, with a good etched tan surface. Up in the nose: cocoa, so much chocolate this year, its insane....and I dig it. Coffee comes through in the secondary, and then the vanilla bourbon notes come through. I gotta say, nosewise, that this is beautiful, but no longer worth the trouble on the nose aspect vs. FBS for me. Flavor, vanilla, bourbon and american oak up front, upon moving to the posterior lingual aspects, I get an alcohol burn and some nice cocoa, but really more bourbon character - okay, this is way better than FBS, but still, in the current trade market, not quite $ worth it for me vs. Abyss. Smooth, but a bit hollow with a litter higher carb than Id prefer in this style. All around great brew, worth at least two or three tries. Really admire everything Founders does. 4/3.5/4.5/3/4- 

Thanks to Chaney for this brew!
Bottled 02/2010
2nd time: bottled 02/2011 - sampled 3/2011 4/4.5/4.5/4.5/4.5/4.48
Poured to NB Globe at around 50F
A: Deep, dark, black ale with opacity which it seems difficult to overcome. No light, not even at the edge of the beer. No carbonation evident, just black, thick beer. When agitated, can get a small appearance to provide evidence of carbonation.
A2: Same as above. Add thick quilt of dark mocha head which hangs around. Little lacing.
S: Coffee, dark chocolate, hints of bourbon, good and sweet vanilla tones intertwine with plenty of malt goodness. This develops over the course of the beer and further accentuates the the chocolate tones.
S2: Coffee again. You know, the bourbon is just not here, too much coffee! 
T: Wow. Its the most chocolate Ive ever experienced in a beer. Dark, +85% pure, but chocolate nonetheless. I almost want this beer to be served warm, oddly. So much coffee continues to highlight this beer, and I cant think but wonder how they did this. Just delightful. Just a hint spicy and hot with the alcohol. 
T2: More coffee this time around. Still no bourbon. Why dont they just skip the barrel? Lakes and East Coast seem to be obsessed with coffee beer. okay, okay, theres bourbon on the back end, but not substantial. Okay beer, not as good as the homers make out.
M: Heavy, thick, sticky. Dries the tongue, dries my life. Sucks me dry and compels me to fill my mouth with more of the seductive beer. Low carbonation. Well played.
M2: see above.
O: This beer is good, no doubt. My problem is with the bal presence. Heres the thing, if you want to have a coffee beer, have a coffee beer. If you want to have a BBA beer, have a BBA beer. If you want to have a BBA/coffee beer, learn to balance them. I cant say I will pursue this as aggressively next year. Its just not that great. Good yes.

Serving type: bottle

05-03-2012

Thickest darkest brown with a lacing whisked tan filmy head. Oily and near antiseptic booze, like heavy duty choc and bourbon lip salve. Initial taste is crisp and clean vanilla, probably the most impressive part of this for me - crystallised sweetness without being sticky or sickly. Increibly rich mouthfeel, tempered by a bourbon peppery lick on the palate. Sumptuous popping booze on the linger, crackling wood and a linger of cloudy gritty choc. Lovely, but I was expecting to be blown away. Bottle, Cheers Ben and more importantly Mike/Bythemmisisisis

Bottle, thanks Mike. Shared with the biggest bell end I could find. Black witg tan head that fades away. Aroma of chocolate, wood, licorice, vanilla. Taste of vanilla, wood, chocolate and licorice, some dark fruits, alcohol. Its not very thick (thats what she said ;)) but clean finish with an alcohol hum. Very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2015 Revising the original 5 rating. I was incredibly drunk long ago. 12 oz bottle from 2015. The pour is a dark black with a thin mocha head and some soapy lace. The aroma is full of chocolate and roasted malt. I like the coffee, though its reserved from years past. The flavor is much of the same. This is good, but the bourbon heat is more dominant. The chocolate and coffee are a little more relaxed and the barrel is prevalent. The mouth feel is lighter than I was hoping, but its still decently thick. There is a decent carbonation but its not as good as I remember. The aftertaste is lingeringly bitter roast and good bourbon chocolate. This isnt as good as I remembered. Still good

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2014 Thanks to Lukaduke for giving me my first taste of this beast a few weeks back. Doing a proper rating for #200 with a bottle thanks to Bvdubn. And thanks to the unexpected genrousity of bytemesis for giving me a bottle, which gave me an excuse to drink the one I previously had in my cellar! This is the 2013 version, 12oz bottle pours black with small half finger of tan head. Nose is rich chocolate, coffee, cream, subtle bourbon, subtle dark fruit, strong and complex. Taste is creamy dark chocolate, dark roast bitter coffee, mocha, very subtle fruit notes, the bourbon is almost at a level of perfection in the layers of this beer after about 8 months in the bottle. The mouthfeel is unbelievably silky and smooth, not too thick or too thin. Not boozy at all. The finish is bitter dark chocolate, faint smoky ash, vanilla, and a lasting subdued fruity warmth from the bourbon which hugs every inch of the mouth. Incredible.
I got very lucky getting to tired this awesome beer a very strong a complex aroma a dark thick head and hints of coffee i love this beer

Holy moly. Could this be my new favorite beer? Aroma is a bit of light chocolate and the head dissipated quickly. However, all the action is in the taste. Deep dark coffee with a thick chocolate finish. Ultra smooth velvety mouthfeel (like a milk stout). My mouth feels like I just ate chocolate. Cant detect the alcohol in this at all. Received via trade.

FROM NOTES: November 29, 13 on draft into a snifter at the Black Friday event @ Kraftrwork, Philly.

A: Big nose full of roasty malts, subtle vanilla dark chocolate notes, roasted coffee and bourbon (booze). 
A: Blackest of night with the tannest of tan heads of about a finger and a half thick. VERY SEXY!
T: Dark chocolate notes initially that give way to some espresso/coffee notes with the bourbon becoming more evident in the finish. Aftertaste has a balance between the bourbon and the coffee flavors with the bourbon dominating more as it warms.
P: Creamy, chewy and silky with a nice low carbonation. Surprisingly very smooth for a beer that is 11.2%!
O: Outstanding beer. WORLD CLASS! Very complex. Coffee, chocolate, and bourbon are the primary flavors, as advertised to be. VERY, VERY RARELY does a beer truly live up to the hype, this is that rare example.

Bottle share from Edgar. Thanks brotha! Pours a jet black with a deep tan thin head in a snifter. Powerful aroma of coffee, vanilla, hint of chocolate, bourbon and roasted malts. The taste was amazing with deep roasted malts, dark chocolate, vanilla, light coffee and dark fruits. Full body, some carbonation. Finishes strong with a full bourbon oaked flavor. Lived up to the hype. Very very good.

Gorgeous dark brew. Thin to non existent head. Wonderfully tasteful a very full body. Almost need to chew. Tastes come in the second half of the mouth. Chocolatey coffee

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: DEC 1, 2013 Wow. Big coffee flavor. Perfect ratio of chocolate, coffee, and bourbon. Fantastic. Really blown away.

Part of the rare stout tappings at the Flying Saucer SA. Served in a snifter. Dark rich hue with great lacing. A significant but not overpowering bourbon presence in the aroma. Great balance to this beer that makes it very enjoyable to drink. Roasted coffee. Some dry fruit lends complexity. A moderate alcohol note of the finish.

Yes this beer is awesome. Personally I dont love "coffee" beers, but there is alot of other good stuff going on in this one. Aroma smacks of coffee, but also some creamy sweetness. Taste has less coffee - just heavily roasted malt - and more of the sweet malt and barrel notes. the beer finishes with coffee flavors. Palate is good - full/thick with a sticky sweet finish. Overall really tasty, but I have a hard time justifying the hype. Mostly that relates to my personal distaste for outright coffee flavors.

12oz bottle compliments of AndyReynolds - pours black with light brown head. Nose is wood,bourbon and coffee. Sips adds booze, roast/burnt coffee and dark fruit. I had coffee breath before and still do. Complex bitterness. Vanilla aftertaste.

A: Dark Opqaue Hue, Passes No Light, Brownish Head Ring, Some Lacing

S: Espresso, Bitter Coffee, Chocolate, Mild Bourbon, Mildly Nutty

T: Coffee, Chocolate, Mild Bourbon

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium to Full Bodied, Mildly Bitter

Overall, this beer is what it is...I just wish that there was more of a barrel presence in it but the coffee either overtook it or the barrel just was prominent enough. Great Trade Bait.

Bottle courtesy of canihavefourbeers. Strong chocolate nose bunts of booze and vanilla. Taste is the same. Think this one may be an older bottle as the coffe is muted. Great beer though. Could drink this all day. They should can this. Slightly bitter as I drink more.

Bottle from trade via unknown. Pours very dark, little to no tan head. Aroma Bourbon, peanuts/almonds, chocolate, roasty. Body huge, nutty, roasty/charred oak. Finish surprisingly subtle, really nice.

29/IX/13 - 12Fl. Oz. bottle @ American BBQ and beertasting, my place - BB: n/a - bottled: II/2012 (2013-914) Very big thanks to Jeremy for the bottle!
Clear dark brown to black beer, aery to creamy beige head, little stable, non adhesive. Aroma: lots of chloride, caramel, sugary, some tobacco. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: caramel, sugary, spicy, dried fruits, jam, sour red berries, mocha, some coffee. Aftertaste: caramel, mocha, bit sugary, some dried fruits, dark chocolate, liquorish, pretty hoppy and dry ending. Nice beer, but I was expecting more of this one...

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2015 shared 2011 bottle. poured black as motor oil, with a small disappearing mocha coloured head. aroma is full of chocolate, bourbon, and coffee. combined with sweet vanilla flavours some roasted malts. best to drink it a bit warm. because the bourbon is way better than. fantastic beer! to bad its always a pain in the ass to get these beers over here in holland

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2015 In a 2011 bottle, Pours slick black with a little red.Great boutbon coffee and chocolate aroma...taste has a little heat a lot of coffee and some chocolate, a little less bourbon than I had hoped finish is too dry for style, but still fantastic!

Black smooth and very nice. Booze hit you hard and mellows into chocolate. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Black as oil with a laced brown head. The aroma is filled with molasses, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and roasted malts. The oak bourbon barrel aging blends perfectly into the smooth, rich, velvety palate and flavors.

What else needs to be said? Big, boozy and beautiful. I appreciate Founders attention to detail. Not overpowering but enough kick to know the bourbon is there. Worth the wait in tracking this down. Cant wait to find some for the cellar.
Black in the glass. Smoky bacon aroma. Smooth creamy chocolate flavor. Overall, very very nice! Thanks to BZK for his generosity!

This is stout heaven - strong dark chocolate, espresso, and bourbon on those nose. All three qualities come through in the mouthfeel and body, yet its surprisingly thin, which is disappointing, especially for such a sought-after beer like this. Nevertheless, it finishes with a lot of heat and is bodacious.

mocha beige head disappears fast with some lacing. coffee colour. aroma of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, boozy, earthy. taste like aroma with a boozy finish. warm mouthfeel, quite dense body, rather soft carbonation. nice, lives up to its expectation.  bottle 35.5 cl

Bottle split with Big Al (a several over the years). Pours a black with thin mocha head, no lace. Nose of roasted malt, coffee, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, oak. Medium to full body. Tons of coffee, light vanilla and bourbon, roasted malt flavors. Light carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2014 Re-rate 6/30/14: Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer Market Jaffa. Thanks Tom L. Black with a light brown head. Amazing coffee beans aroma with roast, bourbon, dark chocolate and a bit of vanilla. Sweet roasty flavor, a bit bitterish, with dark chocolate, lots of coffee beans, a bit of bourbon and a vanilla and a light alcoholic hint. Full-bodied. Really great stuff. 9/4/8/4/17=4.2

[10/4/13] Bottle sample at a tasting at chrisos place. Thanks jsquire! Black with a tiny bit of light shining through and a bit of light brown foam. Lovely aroma with lots of coffee, some dark chocolate, some wood and bourbon. Sweet roasty flavor, bourbon, with dark chocolate, coffee and hazelnuts notes. Great full thick body, rounded mouthfeel. Great stuff. 8/4/8/5/16=4.1
12 oz bottle. Oily black pour with a thin dark brown head. Aroma of faint bourbon, molasses, bitter chocolate and vanilla. Thick mouthfeel with a lasting warming alcohol finish.

On tap in tulip from Birch Hill Tavern: Pours black with a dark tan one-finger head. Aroma is roasted coffee, bourbon, chocolate, and dark malts. So much flavor in every tiny sip. The bourbon is really present in a fresh batch, as is the coffee. Coats the mouth with smooth, sticky perfection. All this said, I still prefer regular Breakfast Stout, but its just preference. Bourbon barrel aged beers add a certain sweetness to a beer, and one of the characteristics of FBS that I love is the packed in flavor with very little sweetness. This is a world-class beer.

12oz bottle, DSG and jsquire tasting at Chris. Many thanks jsquire! It pours a deep black color with a small brown head. Aroma is deeply roasted coffee, chocolate, bourbon notes of vanilla. Flavor is roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Some wood and vanilla notes but extremely well integrated and not overpowering as some other BA RISs. Viscous, full bodied. An outstanding beer for sure, especially for how it packs a loads of flavours without anyone being overwhelming. The closest one to Kaggen Ive ever tried.
Holy shit this is amazing. Aroma of coffee, toffee, bourbon, vanilla bean. Taste is just amazing. Great coffee flavor, hint of bourbon and smooth.
Dsg tasting at Chriss. Aroma is treacle caramel light roast and higher alcohols. Thick viscous black small reluctant head. Flavour us sweet treacle vanilla coffee and warming. Tasty big sweet stout.

Pours a pitch black with a brown head that dissipates pretty quickly leaving behind a small finish.

Smells of chocolate and Kentucky err...bourbon with maybe a bit of vanilla. 

Oh my gosh this is amazing. I hadnt had one of these since early in my craft beer journey and its even better than I remember. 

Lots of chocolate at the beginning rounding into a little bitterness and smooth alcohol finishes with a bourbon kick and some lingering bitterness. The bourbon is INCREDIBLY smooth. Some bourbon beers are way too harsh for my tastes, but this is perfect. You can taste the bourbon, but its not overpowering.

Not quite as syrupy as some stouts which is good. Very little to no carbonation which again is perfect for the style.

Im very glad I bought this guys three friends as well. In fact, I may go back tomorrow to buy a few more. One of the best beers Ive ever had.

So excited to get ahold of this one! Did not disappoint!

Draft into pint glass - 
The aroma was of deep, rich coffee; chocolate and bourbon. It was very deep brown/black with little head. The taste was lead by coffee with a predominately sweet bourbon kick at the finish.

This was so good, I opted for another. The ABV snuck up on me mid-way through the second glass. This has quickly moved up my list of favorites.

On Tap.

Wow. Imagine sitting at a local diner in Bardstown KY. At the other end of the restaurant is an old man smoking a sweet cigar. You are eating some bourbon pancakes in maple syrup and drinking chocolate milk. Sounds disgusting, but take those subtle tones, merry them together in which nothing overpowers the next, and this is what comes out.

This is a wonderful beer. I love it.

Excellent. Heavy chocolate aroma, some bourbon but not much. Taste is a great blend of deep chocolate, roasted coffee, bourbon, and sweetness. Sweetness is not cloying or overdone. This is all about balance. Nothing overpowers, nothing lingers in the background. Finesse. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wow. Smokey malty hints of chocolate and strong after taste of Kentucky bourbon. Almost like you took a shot after the first sip. Then it mellows out on your palate and everything just goes perfect with one another. 

So happy I got to try. Wasnt sure how you can make breakfast stout better but Founders found a way.
This is one of the greats that we can try and get every year. Great color and a huge flavor but not over the top

Bottle (thanks art!) rating #500

Aroma: Nuts, bourbon, wood

Appearance: Pitch black with brown head.

Taste: Quite complex; coffee, smokey wood, bourbon

Palate: Medium mouthfeel, big and chewy, although pretty drinkable. Smooth, slightly flat mouthfeel. 

Overall: Not a new concept, but extremely good and different than other bourbon barrel stouts. Vanilla adds a sweetness, and the coffee leads the way on the taste front.
This is an amazing stout. Very complex flavors of chocolate, burnt malts, vanilla, bourbon. Oh man is it good. Find it and drink it.

Pours black with 1/2 inch tan head. Aromas of cocoa, coffee even a hint of vanilla. Taste follows nose. Really smooth finish with just a hint of bitterness. Soft Medium body. Excellent. Lived up to the hype. One of my favorite beers so far.

An extra from umich43jm. Wow, thanks! Pours deep lack with a tiny brown head. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, molasses, raisin and dark chocolate. Smells amazing! Flavors of dark malt, coffee, vanilla, oak, raisin. Lots going on. Very nice.
If you like a good dark beer, this is for you. Definitely a sipper.. very chocolately. Fabled for a reason. Tan head. Dark body. Stout with a abv to back it up. Glory in a glass.

Comparison between a 2010 and 2013 bottle. Pours a deep brown/black. Little to no carbonation on both, slightly more on 13. 10 has a much more prominent bourbon smell while 13 is more coffee forward. 10 has a nice boozy bourbon taste with coffee aftertaste while 13 is very coffee forward an a little more bitter. Both excellent. Smooth non-carbonated mouthfeel.

Flat out favorite beer. It would be a great stout to start with then its aged in bourbon barrels. The coffee and chocolate has a massive presence then a slight hint of bourbon on the back end to balance everything out. Hard to believe its over 11%. Dangerously smooth. Only problem is its very limited production.

On tap at Redlight Redlight in Orlando for Zwanze Day 2013. Pours pitch black with a brown head and great aroma of coffee and vanilla. Taste is smooth, lots of great balancing of coffee, vanilla, chocolate, and bourbon with a long, pleasant warming finish. Delicious stout, the bourbon isnt overpowering and the flavors come together really nicely to make a very drinkable, strong, flavorful stout

Absolutely phenomenal. Luscious jet black color with a deep, dirty caramel head. Tastes thick and creamy with just the perfect level of sweetness and alcohol to compliment the bourbon tones. A lot of barrrel aged beers promise an oaky flavor but very few deliver on the promise, this really does have an incredibly subtle yet prominent bourbon barrel aftertaste, and the coffee/vanilla mix on the tongue isnt just well balanced, it fuses to create a remarkably perfect stout. Never pass up the chance to give this a try.

2013. pitch black with a small creamy brown head with short retention and good lacing. chocolate, bourbon, oak, vanilla, booze, coffee. bourbon is big, but its not so big that it overpowers the rest of the beer, which seems to be the norm for bourbon barrel stouts. medium-heavy sweet, heavy bitter. full body, thick and creamy feel, soft carb, moderately hot. its good, really good, but its honestly way overrated.
Bottle. Black with tan head. Aroma of chocolate and malts. Sweet and hoppy taste. Lingering palate. Great beer.
Vintage bottle. Pours dark opaque black with toffee colored head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Taste of coffee and bourbon. Very amazing.

Finally got a chance to taste this once and a lifetime brew. It was everything an imperial stout was that the Pliny elder was to the IPA.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Complex, bold with bourbon undertones . easy to drink, great flavor on palate well after consuming this world class stout.

Hauntingly complex. On a wine parallel it reminds me of a deep cabernet. Bourbon reminded me of an old friend- dependable and comfortable. Wish and hope founders offers this annually. Simply too good to hoard.

---all in good suds.

A great blend of coffee, vanilla and hint of bourbon. What you are looking for in a great stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Had this on tap up on Grand Rapids. Wow. I could have this for breakfast every morning. Slightly roasty but with lots of coffee and dark chocolate. Great beer.
I was lucky enough to get a chance to try.4of us sample a bottle warm. Very stong burbon taste.

2012 version. Pours black as night with a quarter finger of a dark mocha colored head that dissipates very quick and leaves an extremely thin ring of lacing. Smells of lots of roasted coffee, some bourbon, oak, vanilla, roasted malts, some dark chocolate. Taste starts with coffee, dark chocolate, some oak, and roasted malts. Then the middle brings more sweetness. Notes of molasses and carmel join the darker coffee, chocolate, and roasty notes. The finish is just fantastic. Strong, yet not overbearing notes of bourbon, vanilla, and oak come into the picture and meld with the now stronger notes of roasted coffee and dark chocolate. The bourbon, oak, and vanilla get stronger as it warms; yet it does not get hot at all. It simply makes the beer more complex and flavorful. Surprisingly thin for a beer of this magnitude. High medium body with a creamy mouthfeel. Not enough good things to say about this beer. Its smoothness makes it stand out from a lot of other barrel aged stouts. Extremely well done.
Bottled. Smell chocolate coffee and alcohol. Pour motor oil black with a very little tan head. Taste chocolate, coffee, vanilla, cinnamon, and bourbon. Medium body. This is a great beer!

Many thanks to my friend Art for sending this one my way.  Pours an opaque dark brown with a dark mocha head. If the head retained longer, itd make for a unique, rich, gorgeous beer. Milk chocolate syrup, chocolate liqueur, coffee, and greasy spoon griddle smoke aromas. Mouthfeel not quite as viscous as one would expect. Somewhat palate coating. Some muted sweetness. The griddle and campfire smokiness comes through more prominently in the flavor. Chocolate ice cream right at the finish just before the bitterness takes hold. Great brew!

12 ounce bottle from Timfoolery, great beer, no head, bourbon is very mild, coffee is pretty big. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

355 ml bottle shared with czar - thanks, mate. Pours pitch black with a short lived beige-brown head. Aroma is chocolate, wood, bourbon, hazelnut. Flavor is dark, dark, dark chocolate, port wine, hazelnut, wood, brown sugar, bourbon. Finish is hazelnut and brown toast. Lingering wood. Warmish sensation. Medium body, weak carbonation, sticky, oily, unctuous mouthfeel. Very fawkhen solid; the hype was right.

Had fresh on opening day from the brewery. Pours a thick black with a small tan head that retains poorly. This is perhaps the only disappointment for this beer. The aromas are complex, highlighting the coffee, vanilla and chocolate blended with the oakey bourbon taste from the bourbon barrels. A slight alcohol finish, which is surprising considering the high percentage. Soft carbonation and very smooth drinking. Exceptionally crafted beer.

Bottle - Vintage 2012 - Chocolate, coffee, bourbon and oak. Jet black with a persistent brown thin head. Coffee and smooth bourbon. Very nicely rounded and balanced with a bit of alcohol heat. Nice to see a beer where the bourbon adds, not overwhelms.

bottle from tom10101, thanks bro. pours inky black with a small somewhat creamy dark beige head, good retention and lacing. smoked hazelnuts, present but not overwhelming bourbon, roasted and smoked malts, tons of coffee, umami, caramelized mushrooms. soft carbonation, full body - oily and sticky, balanced by a bold peppery-resinous finish. this is great stuff..

2013 12oz bottle poured into snifter. Pours a deep opaque black with no head at all - only a thin ring can be seen after the pour. So deeply black...think "used motor oil" and youll get it. Aroma is of vanilla, liquorice, coffee, dark chocolate, oak and bourbon/alcohol. This is really complex; every single aroma can be perceived and separated. Im far from having the best nose in the world so to me, this is just flabbergasting. Taste is medium sweet and medium-light bitter. Body is rather full with an oily texture. Carbonation is almost non-existent, and its just what I expected. Finish is medium-long, and is concentrated on the oak/bourbon profile. Overall this is an outstanding oak-aged imperial stout. Really balanced too! Ive tasted many others which were way too focused on oak aromas and sometimes I had "issues" finishing the bottle because it was just way too much. Simply put: you have to try it at least once thats for sure. From now on, I think I will be a regular and buy my two KBS every year. Cheers!
Bottle at Novare Res. Smells amazing, of bourbon. Tastes of vanilla, toffee. Medium-full body. Finishes with a boozy semi-bitter bourbon. Absolutely Awesome.
12oz Bottle, Prefer to have this fresh but also nice with a few years age on it. Always one of my favs. Look forward to its release every year.

Absolutely one of my favorites. Look forward to it each year. Prefer it fresh but still excellent with a year or two of age on it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours pitch black with a small tan head. Smells strongly of coffee, chocolate, and bourbon. Taste is bourbon, and coffee. Full-bodied with a slick, silky texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Founders Kentucky Breakfast Stout finishes with a coffee bourbon kick.

On draft. Black with a tan head. Aroma is coffee and boubon. Taste is outstanding! Well-balanced with notes of coffee, bourbon, oak, vanilla, chocolaten, and cherry. Very smooth with a great finish. The coffee and oak lingers but is not overwhelming. An outstanding beer!
2013. Big coffee, mmmm chocolate, a bit sweet. Hearty roast, great blend of flavors. I give this beer shit from time to time but repent every time I drink one. Delicious.

Bottle at my place with Taylor, Thomas, and Chad. Aroma of rubbing alcohol, chocolate, coffee, vanilla. Taste of rough coffee and vanilla. Finish is savory long and chocolaty with coffee. Delicious. Medium to heavy mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from trade with nimbleprop, many thanks.almost black colored beer with medium espresso beige head. Roasted coffee, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, oak. Taste, milk chocolate, coffee, vanilla, peat, ash, brown sugar, cream, bourbon, wood. Alcohol comes through while warming. Very smooth, well balanced extremely tasty Imperial stout.

I absolutely loved this near perfect beer. By far the best stout Ive had to date; however, Im drinking my first Speedway tonight. I really enjoyed how smooth and mellow the chocolate, coffee, smoke flavors mixed together. I highly recommend pairing with some dark chocolate for a late night desert.

Draft. Black with a 1 finger tan head. Nose is chocolate and bourbon. First sip is unbelievable. Opens with a huge chocolate note fading to lots of woody barrel notes. Big wave of vanilla finishes it off. Subsequent sips are a lot boozier but still hit all the right notes. Palate is rich without being syrupy and overwhelming. I guess there's been a lot of backlash against this one but I think the hype is richly deserved. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had this many times, but this was a special treat for me and my son. It was the last day of Philly Beer Week, and we were at Misconduct. The bar was empty, so we were able to enjoy a few in peace and quite. My son wished to attend a few events featuring this beer but it had kicked before he arrived. 

As for the beer, there is no finer Coffee Stout that I am aware of! And yes, I have had CBS before.
